biogHists.text:
Robert Burton House was executive secretary, 1926-1934, dean of administration, 1934-1945, and chancellor, 1945-1957, of the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill campus; lecturer in the UNC English Department, 1957-1962; author; and public speaker.

From the description of R. B. House papers, 1916-1973. WorldCat record id: 30485688

relations.content: Connor, R. D. W. (Robert Digges Wimberly), 1878-1950.
University United Methodist Church (Chapel Hill, N.C.)

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:43034501</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-NGB</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Prouty, William W.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>William W. Prouty photographic collection, circa 1955-1961.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of approximately 7,500 images documenting community organizations; events; businesses; churches; schools; sports teams; newsworthy people of local and national significance; and scenes and activities in and around the towns of Chapel Hill, Carrboro, and Hillsborough in Orange County, N.C., between 1955 and 1961. The collection also contains some images of the University of North Carolina, including a set of 35mm color copy slides of the October 1961 University Day visit of President John F. Kennedy. A few North Carolina coastal and mountain locations are also depicted. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Oceanside Free Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: William W. Prouty photographic collection, circa 1955-1961.
resource.abstract: The collection consists of approximately 7,500 images documenting community organizations; events; businesses; churches; schools; sports teams; newsworthy people of local and national significance; and scenes and activities in and around the towns of Chapel Hill, Carrboro, and Hillsborough in Orange County, N.C., between 1955 and 1961. The collection also contains some images of the University of North Carolina, including a set of 35mm color copy slides of the October 1961 University Day visit of President John F. Kennedy. A few North Carolina coastal and mountain locations are also depicted.
resource.displayEntry: Prouty, William W. William W. Prouty photographic collection, circa 1955-1961.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:43034504</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-NGB</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Wilson, Louis Round, 1876-1979.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Louis Round Wilson photographic collection, circa 1860s-1980s.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Louis Round Wilson Photographic Collection consists largely of snapshots of family and friends and some studio portraits, circa 1860s-1980s. Family snapshots include members of the Edmonds, Round, Wilson, and Wright families. Among the individual images are those of William C. Friday, R.B. House, and Thomas Wolfe. Most photographs were made in North Carolina (primarily in Chapel Hill), but a few were made in Chicago, New York, and elsewhere. Formats represented include black-and-white prints, color prints and negatives, silhouettes, a daguerreotype, ambrotypes, tintypes, a cyanotype, postcards, and cartes de visites. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Oceanside Free Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.abstract: The Louis Round Wilson Photographic Collection consists largely of snapshots of family and friends and some studio portraits, circa 1860s-1980s. Family snapshots include members of the Edmonds, Round, Wilson, and Wright families. Among the individual images are those of William C. Friday, R.B. House, and Thomas Wolfe. Most photographs were made in North Carolina (primarily in Chapel Hill), but a few were made in Chicago, New York, and elsewhere. Formats represented include black-and-white prints, color prints and negatives, silhouettes, a daguerreotype, ambrotypes, tintypes, a cyanotype, postcards, and cartes de visites.
resource.displayEntry: Wilson, Louis Round, 1876-1979. Louis Round Wilson photographic collection, circa 1860s-1980s.

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:505946057</recordOrigin>

                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Giduz, Roland.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Roland Giduz photographic collection, 1947-1970.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection comprises approximately 19,000 negatives made between circa 1947 and circa 1970, primarily in Chapel Hill and Carrboro, N.C. Subject matter includes people, places, activities, and events. The collection includes photographs relating to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and a few other places within the state. The negatives are grouped by locality, subject, and personal name. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Oceanside Free Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

The collection includes photographs relating to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and a few other places within the state. The negatives are grouped by locality, subject, and personal name.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:466453237</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-NGB</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Morton, Hugh M.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Hugh Morton photographs and films: People and events, late 1920s-early 2000s (bulk 1940s-1990s) (Series 2).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This series consists of approximately 39,500 images of individuals, groups, and events, both identified and unidentified. The images in People and Events date from the late 1920s through the early 2000s, with the bulk from the 1940s through the 1990s. With the exception of "Singing on the Mountain" images considered for or used in "Making a Difference" (and thus included in subseries 2.1), annual events that take place at Grandfather Mountain can be found in Series 4. With regard to sports figures (athletes and coaches including Michael Jordan, Dean Smith, and Charlie Justice), additional portraits that show them actively engaged in their sport(s) can be found in Series 6.1. With the exception of sports images included in subseries 2.1, the images of sports figures in the People and Events series depict them off the court/field. Because People and Events contains portraits of both individuals and various types of groups (including couples, family groups, organizational activities, meetings, performances, etc.), all images of a specific person may not be found in the same subseries. (For example, images of Terry Sanford can be found in subseries 2.1, 2.6, and 2.8, and are in some cases listed under the names of other individuals, e.g., Johnson, Lyndon Baines and Kennedy, John F. in subseries 2.6). </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Oceanside Free Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Hugh Morton photographs and films: People and events, late 1920s-early 2000s (bulk 1940s-1990s) (Series 2).
resource.abstract: This series consists of approximately 39,500 images of individuals, groups, and events, both identified and unidentified. The images in People and Events date from the late 1920s through the early 2000s, with the bulk from the 1940s through the 1990s. With the exception of "Singing on the Mountain" images considered for or used in "Making a Difference" (and thus included in subseries 2.1), annual events that take place at Grandfather Mountain can be found in Series 4. With regard to sports figures (athletes and coaches including Michael Jordan, Dean Smith, and Charlie Justice), additional portraits that show them actively engaged in their sport(s) can be found in Series 6.1. With the exception of sports images included in subseries 2.1, the images of sports figures in the People and Events series depict them off the court/field. Because People and Events contains portraits of both individuals and various types of groups (including couples, family groups, organizational activities, meetings, performances, etc.), all images of a specific person may not be found in the same subseries. (For example, images of Terry Sanford can be found in subseries 2.1, 2.6, and 2.8, and are in some cases listed under the names of other individuals, e.g., Johnson, Lyndon Baines and Kennedy, John F. in subseries 2.6).
resource.displayEntry: Morton, Hugh M. Hugh Morton photographs and films: People and events, late 1920s-early 2000s (bulk 1940s-1990s) (Series 2).

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:26319995</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-NGB</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Love, James Lee, 1860-1950.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>James Lee Love papers, 1880-1954 [manuscript].</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of correspondence and other papers related to Love's association with the University of North Carolina, the North Carolina textile industry, including the Gastonia Cotton Manufacturing Company and Burlington Mills, and many philanthropies. Correspondents include Alexander Boyd Andrews, Graham Hudson Anthony, Thomas Barbour, Thomas Hart Benton, Albert Coates, James Bryant Conant, Frank Porter Graham, J. G. de Roulhac Hamilton, Paul H. Hanus, Archibald Henderson, Thomas Felix Henderson, Robert Burton House, Walter Lippman, James Spencer Love, William DeBerniere McNider, Rabbi Stephen Wise, and Samuel Bryant Turrentine. Also included are papers of James Lee Love's father, Robert Calvin Grier Love, and son, James Spencer Love, both textile executives; detailed memoirs of J. L. Love's childhood in Gaston County, N.C., and of his academic career at the University of North Carolina and Harvard, especially his connection with the Lawrence Scientific School; and a framed oil portrait of him by Phillip H. Giddens. An addition to the collection consists mainly of correspondence between J. L. Love and his first wife, June Spencer Love (died 1920) and their children, including Cornelia (born 1892) and James Spencer, concerning family, career, and academic matters. These letters date mostly from the summers of 1892, 1893 and 1911. Other letters are from various family members, particularly Cornelia P. Spencer and Laura Battle Phillips. Also included are volumes and pictures. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Oceanside Free Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Giddens. An addition to the collection consists mainly of correspondence between J. L. Also included are volumes and pictures.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:30485688</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-NGB</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>House, R. B. (Robert Burton), 1892-1987.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>R. B. House papers, 1916-1973.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Correspondence, writings, and other materials chiefly relating to House's administrative career at UNC. Much of the correspondence centers around administrative problems, especially budgetary issues. There are also letters in which House expressed his views on race relations, Communism in the 1950s, and other topics. Among the correspondents are Josephus Daniels, Harry Chase, William Umstead, singer Kate Smith, Francis O. Clarkson, R. D. W. Connor, Frank Porter Graham, Gordon Gray, Jonathan Daniels, Carl T. Durham, O. Max Gardner, Terry Sanford, Hardin Craig, and Louis R. Wilson. Also included are some family correspondence with House's Thelma, Halifax County, N.C., relatives, and letters and other materials relating to House's activities with the University United Methodist Church and to his harmonica playing at speeches and on television. Writings include numerous speeches, reviews, and radio addresses relating to UNC, to North Carolina history, and to House's historical sketch of Sallie Drake Twitty. Pictures are chiefly photographs of House at official UNC functions. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Oceanside Free Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: R. B. House papers, 1916-1973.
resource.abstract: Correspondence, writings, and other materials chiefly relating to House's administrative career at UNC. Much of the correspondence centers around administrative problems, especially budgetary issues. There are also letters in which House expressed his views on race relations, Communism in the 1950s, and other topics. Among the correspondents are Josephus Daniels, Harry Chase, William Umstead, singer Kate Smith, Francis O. Clarkson, R. D. W. Connor, Frank Porter Graham, Gordon Gray, Jonathan Daniels, Carl T. Durham, O. Max Gardner, Terry Sanford, Hardin Craig, and Louis R. Wilson. Also included are some family correspondence with House's Thelma, Halifax County, N.C., relatives, and letters and other materials relating to House's activities with the University United Methodist Church and to his harmonica playing at speeches and on television. Writings include numerous speeches, reviews, and radio addresses relating to UNC, to North Carolina history, and to House's historical sketch of Sallie Drake Twitty. Pictures are chiefly photographs of House at official UNC functions.
resource.displayEntry: House, R. B. (Robert Burton), 1892-1987. R. B. House papers, 1916-1973.

resource.source:
Grandfather Mountain with Turk's Cap Lily; P081_PRCP0_001930, in the Hugh Morton Photographs and Films #P0081, North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, The Wilson Library, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

 University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Library. North Carolina Collection. Morton, Hugh M. Hugh Morton Photographs and Films, late 1920s-2006 (bulk 1940s-1990s) P0081 Materials in English About 250,000 Hugh MacRae Morton (1921-2006) was a prominent North Carolina businessman, political figure, tourism booster, conservationist, environmental activist, sports fan, and prolific image-maker. The still images and motion pictures in the collection cover Morton's career of eight decades, 1930s-2000s, and document his varied involvements as a photojournalist; a soldier in the Pacific Theater during World War II; the owner and operator of the Grandfather Mountain tourist attraction in Linville, N.C.; a promoter of travel and tourism in North Carolina and the Smoky Mountains region; a well-known figure in state government and friend of many North Carolina politicians, entertainers, and media; a student, booster, and frequent sports-event attendee of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill; and an ardent admirer of nature.
resource.title: Hugh Morton Photographs and Films,   late1920s-2006 (bulk1940s-1990s)
resource.abstract: Hugh MacRae Morton (1921-2006) was aprominent North Carolina businessman, political figure, tourism booster,conservationist, environmental activist, sports fan, and prolificimage-maker. The still images and motion pictures in the collectioncover Morton's career of eight decades, 1930s-2000s, and document his variedinvolvements as a photojournalist; a soldier in the Pacific Theater during World WarII; the owner and operator of the Grandfather Mountain tourist attraction inLinville, N.C.; a promoter of travel and tourism in North Carolina and the SmokyMountains region; a well-known figure in state government and friend of many NorthCarolina politicians, entertainers, and media; a student, booster, and frequentsports-event attendee of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill; and anardent admirer of nature.
resource.displayEntry: Hugh Morton Photographs and Films,  , late 1920s-2006, (bulk 1940s-1990s)

nameEntries.original: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Library. North Carolina Collection.

resourceRelations.content: Hugh Morton Photographs and Films,  , late 1920s-2006, (bulk 1940s-1990s)

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:668111954</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-NGB</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Lauterer, Jock.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Jock Lauterer photographic collection, circa 1964-1968.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection is predominantly composed of images of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the town of Chapel Hill, N.C., made from circa 1964-1968, when the photographer was an undergraduate student at UNC. The largest grouping of negatives documents the UNC Men's Glee Club European Tour of 1966. Other images portray life in Chapel Hill, the UNC campus, and university activities. Lauterer captured small-town life; the serenity of campus; sporting events; and the effects of politically charged times on a small community, including anti-war protests, Speaker Ban protests, civil rights marches and speeches, and a Ku Klux Klan rally. Many of the images include persons of national or local significance. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Oceanside Free Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Jock Lauterer photographic collection, circa 1964-1968.
resource.abstract: The collection is predominantly composed of images of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the town of Chapel Hill, N.C., made from circa 1964-1968, when the photographer was an undergraduate student at UNC. The largest grouping of negatives documents the UNC Men's Glee Club European Tour of 1966. Other images portray life in Chapel Hill, the UNC campus, and university activities. Lauterer captured small-town life; the serenity of campus; sporting events; and the effects of politically charged times on a small community, including anti-war protests, Speaker Ban protests, civil rights marches and speeches, and a Ku Klux Klan rally. Many of the images include persons of national or local significance.

Address by Albert Coates, director of the Institute of Government, to the faculty and alumni of the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill in recognition of twenty-five years of service by Chancellor Robert Burton House : Monday, June 4, 1950 [i.e. 1951].

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:43034511</recordOrigin>

                  <name>
                     <namePart>Friday, William C. (William Clyde)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>William C. Friday photographic collection, 1951-1980s.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of photographs, 1951-1980s, that relate to William C. Friday, primarily his activities as president of the University of North Carolina system. Topics include Friday's inauguration; the 1961 visit of President John F. Kennedy to the University of North Carolina; the UNC Board of Trustees; and Friday's television interview program, North Carolina People, which he began in 1971. Many well-known North Carolinians and other individuals are represented in the images. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Oceanside Free Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: William C. Friday photographic collection, 1951-1980s.
resource.abstract: The collection consists of photographs, 1951-1980s, that relate to William C. Friday, primarily his activities as president of the University of North Carolina system. Topics include Friday's inauguration; the 1961 visit of President John F. Kennedy to the University of North Carolina; the UNC Board of Trustees; and Friday's television interview program, North Carolina People, which he began in 1971. Many well-known North Carolinians and other individuals are represented in the images.
